lines.text: Miss Lloyd, where you going?
I'm going home to Mother. She loves me, even if my clothes are old and ugly.
Why, Miss Lloyd, the colonel loves you, too. It's just because his rheumatism's botherin' him that he's so cranky. My, my, you should hear the things he says. They'd make your hair curl.
Would they really make my hair curl?
Sure would, Miss Lloyd. Look what they did to mine. Come on, now.
I don't want to go up there.
Why, everybody's got to go upstairs, Miss Lloyd, if they wants to go to bed.
But I don't want to.
Look here, will you go if I shows you a new way how to go upstairs?
How can there be a new way to go upstairs?

[to a picture of her grandfather]
You're a bad man to make my mama cry!
Will you tell me a pink story?
If you ain't the beatinest child I ever seen. When you want to hear a blue story, everything in it has got to be blue. And when you want to hear a green story, everything in it has got to be green.
[laughs]
Now, I could tell you a *black* story 'bout my first husband...
What under the sun's goin' on here? What are you doing?
Hello, Grandfather! We were just baptizing Henry Clay.
Baptizing Henry Clay?
Yes, and he must be *awful* bad, because it took two dunks to save him!
Grandfather, do you know any blue stories?

[surprised]
Blue stories? Well, I do... a few.
Tell me one.
I don't know any that I can tell *you.*
Confound you, Walker! Watch what you're doing!
I'm sorry, sir.
If you'd broken that, I'd have broken your head.
Yes, sir.
Someday your temper is going to split you wide open.
Well, I won't call for you to sew me up!
What are you doing here?
Wait, Jack, let me tell him! Father, this is the man I'm going to marry. I knew you would never give your consent, so that's why we were going to elope.
I wanted to come to you, sir, and ask your permission, but?
Silence! Why did you assume that I would object to an honorable marriage?
I know how you feel about the South.
I hate all Yankees.
That's why we didn't come and tell you.

Then you knew you were doing wrong! How can you marry a man who represents everything that a true Southerner should hate? A man who fought against your father, your brother, and all your kinfolk. For all you know, he may have fired the shot that killed your brother!

I was in the war, sir, and though I fought on the other side, the South has always had my admiration and respect. My mother was a Virginian. But might I remind you, sir, that the war has been over for some time.
The war will never be over for me and mine, sir. I want to kill you. I don't know but what I will. Elizabeth, go to your room.
No.
Go to your room, I tell you!
I'm going with Jack!
Elizabeth, when that door closes, it will never open for you again!
Oh, stop chattering, Walker!
Yes, sir.
I don't want to hear all this gossip.
No, sir. I was going to tell you about the cottage, sir, but I suspect you're not interested.
The cottage?
Yes, sir. Someone's moved into it.
Walker! Confound you, why don't you let me know when things are going on around here? Who's moving into the cottage?
I don't know, sir.
It's been empty a long time now, ever since - well, maybe I'd better call on our new neighbors and see what kind of folks they are.
Yes, sir. Having some new neighbors won't make it so lonely 'round here.
Who says it's lonely 'round here?
Not me, no sir!
Anyway, I like it lonely!
Mother, who was that?
Your grandfather.
Why didn't he come in?
He didn't want to.
Did he make you cry?
Mom Beck, why doesn't my grandfather want to come in and see my mother?
Well, he mighty mad at she, and I guess she mad at he.
Why?
Your grandfather get mad when your mama marry your daddy.
But he's her papa, isn't he?
Sure 'nough.
Aren't papas supposed to love their little girls?
Yes, honey, they should.
It seems might funny to me.
It's 'cause all the Lloyds are stubborn. The old colonel is, your mama is, and you is.
I'm not stubborn! Don't you call me that!
Don't you stomp your foot at me. That don't change it, that just proves it.
Don't you dare poke with that old stick!
You'd better learn some respect for your elders.
I won't respect anyone who pokes me with a stick!
For a little girl, you've got a bad temper!
That's your fault.
What? Who are you?
They call me the little colonel.
What under the sun do they call you that for?
Because I'm so much like you.
What? How are you like me?
Because I stop my foot when I get mad, and I get all red in the face! I holler back at people, too!
Look at you! You're a pretty sight. What are you running around the country for, like poor white trash? I don't know who your mother is, but whoever she is, she ought to teach you some manners.

[throwing mud on him]
Don't you dare say anything bad about my mother!
Whose child is that?
How can I tell you, sir, when you don't want nobody to even say her name?
I'm Lloyd Sherman, that's who I am!
Lloyd Sherman!
Come on now, child, your mama's mighty worried about you.
I - I didn't know.
Oh, that's all right. Goodbye, Grandfather.
Colonel, your army is retreatin' right now!
Now that I'm a colonel, can't I play with the boys anymore?
Why, of course you can.
I wish you'd tell my mother that.
I will.
I want to thank you, Bob, for everything.
It's been a great pleasure having you and your family with us, even for so short a time. Quite different from Philadelphia, isn't it?
Yes, indeed. We lived there for six years, but I never got used to the dreadful noise of the horse cars.
Jack told me that you'd sold your house there.
We sold everything, lock, stock, and barrel. Took Greely's advice to go west, and here we are to find our fortune. I'm depending on your help for that.
Oh, there's plenty there for the finding, if we're lucky.
I do wish we didn't have to go back home to Lloydsboro.
Now, dear, we've settled all that.
This wild country is no place for women and children, and where Jack's going it's even rougher. Besides, Jack told me you have a lovely home waiting for you.
Oh, that sounds too grand. It's really just a cottage my mother left me.
Mom Beck, I'm expecting Aunt Sally Tyler for lunch. Will you have enough?
I don't know if I can stretch one small chicken, but as long as the water's runnin', we'll have soup enough.
Well, do the best you can.
[Lloyd picks up a cookie]
Honey, don't eat that now. You'll spoil your lunch.
[Lloyd puts down the cookie]
Is Aunt Sally Tyler my aunt too?
She's your great-aunt, dear.
My great-aunt? Oh, I remember, the big fat one.
You must be very polite to her, dear. She's coming all the way from Louisville to see us.
All right, Mother, I will.
And I only had one shot left. And I aimed my gun, and bang! I killed those three Indians.
Why, Miss Lloyd, did you really do that?
Of course not, that's just a story. And you don't have to call me Miss Lloyd. You can call me Colonel.
Is you a colonel too?
Yes, I am, a real colonel!
You can't be no colonel.
Why not?
'Cause you ain't got no whiskers.
I don't need to have whiskers. I've got temper. That's all you need to be a colonel.
I guess that's right, 'cause all the colonels I ever seen had tempers. I hope you're not a colonel like him over there. If you was, I'd be afeared to play with you!
Why, Miss Lloyd, them's the colonel's flowers!
Well, we're not afraid of the colonel.
Who ain't afraid? Maybe you ain't, but I is.
Now listen, May Lily. You too, Henry Clay. I'm the colonel and you're my men, and in the army you have to obey orders. Forward march!
I don't think I'm gonna like bein' the army.
Aw!

Come on, May Lily, let's make mud pies! We can get a lot of nice round pebbles, and they can be raisins. We'll sprinkle dust over the top, and that can be sugar. We'll just make the finest mud pies you ever saw!
There are some things to be considered besides your pride, Elizabeth. There's the child herself, you know. You ought to think of her interests.
I don't care. I don't want anything from him!
I know, dear, but just the same I say you ought to think of Lloyd. If I were you, I'd let her go over there as often as she pleases. And who knows? It might end in your all making up some day.
Never! Not after the terrible things he said about Jack!
Looky here, honey, if you don't take your nap like a good little gir, Mom Beck won't bring you along to the baptizin'.
Will there be singing?
Sure will, honey, and wailin' too.
Then I'll take my nap.
That's a good little girl.
Looky here, how is Miss Elizabeth?
Oh, her health is all right, but I think she worries 'bout Mister Jack. He better come home pretty soon.
What you mean, you ain't got no m -
[Becky shushes him and points to Lloyd]
Uh... M-O-N-I-E?
Not only that, we's 'most outta F-U-D-E.
Well, looky here, couldn't the K-U-N-E-L give a little L-O-N-E?
You know Miss Elizabeth wouldn't take nothin' from him. Why, before she'd do that, she'd go to the, uh... the... P-O-H-O-S.
[Walker stops walking and stares at her]
P-O-H-O-S?
Yeah, sure, ain't you got no education? The poorhouse!
Oh, no.
Yes, indeed.
If the old colonel ever finds out where we got these sheets, he'll baptize us good.
Didn't I tell you that my men don't have to be afraid of anything? Now, Henry Clay, are you ready? Have you got the right thoughts?
Uh-huh.
Do you believe it'll wash your sins away?
Uh-huh.
All right, come one. One, two, three.
[Lloyd and May Lily dunk Henry Clay in the water]
Hallelujah!
Are you saved?
[Henry Clay shakes his head]
Well, we'll have to do it again. One, two, three.
[Lloyd and May Lily dunk Henry Clay in the water again]
Hallelujah!
Are you saved?
Uh-huh.
Grandfather?
Well, what is it?
I'm sorry I threw mud on you. And I'm sorry I lost my temper. And I'm sorry I took the sheets off your bed.
What? You took my sheets?
I had to have them.
Maria, I've got a young lady here whose clothes need drying.
Yes, sir?
Well, take her!
But Colonel sir, what can I put her in while her clothes is a-dryin'? I ain't got nothin' for a little girl to wear.
Uh, Walker, go up into the attic, and you'll find a small trunk. There may be some clothes in there that will fit Miss Lloyd.
A small trunk in the attic, sir?
Yes, you numbskull! Don't you understand English? Attend to it right away.
[the Colonel leaves]
Do you know whose trunk that is and whose clothes they is?
Course I do. You go on now and fetch them things. We don't want no menfolk 'round here.
With that face, you don't have to worry!
My, my, you is the spittin' image of your mother. You got the same goldy hair and pinky cheeks.
Did my mother have a temper, too?
Yes, indeed she did.
Looks like this old house ain't gonna be lonesome no more.
Play a game with me.
What kind of a game?
Well, it couldn't be tag or prisoner's base, could it?
No, no, it couldn't.
It better be a sit-down game, then. Do you know how to play jacks?
Jacks? Do you play that with cards?
No, with a ball.
Oh, then I don't know how to play it, no. Do you play cribbage?
Cribbage? Is that like hopscotch?
For your years and weight, you're probably the stubbornest person in this county.
You weigh a lot more than I do!
You're going to come see me again, aren't you, even though your mother tells you not to?
Yes, Grandfather, and the next time we play, we won't quarrel.
He's still running a fever. He's going to need very careful nursing and plenty of it.
Mom Beck and I will take care of him.
Yes, but if I were you, I would send Lloyd away until he was well again.
But where can I send her?
There's only one place, Elizabeth, and you mustn't be stubborn about it. He's all alone in that big house, you know, and he'd see that she was properly cared for.
Lloyd has never been away from me for one night in her whole life.
I know, but this house is no place for her now. Let me speak with him and I'll arrange it.
Mother, do I have to stay here very long?
No, dear, just until Papa Jack is well.
You know, I'm gonna be awful lonesome without you.
You're going to be brave, aren't you? You promised you would.
Yes, but when I promised, I didn't know I'd feel this way.
Can that be Lloyd that Becky is carrying?
Hello, Mother! How do you do, Aunt Sally Tyler?
How do you do, dear?
Where have you been?
I've been to see my grandfather, and I threw mud on him.
You threw mud on him?
Yes, because he poked me with a stick. Then I got mad and he got mad, and we hollered at each other.
Oh baby, how could you disgrace Mother by going over there looking like a dirty little beggar?
I didn't beg him for anything.
You've been a very naughty girl, and you're going to be punished. Becky, take her inside. Give her a bath and put her to bed.
Yes'm.
Oh, I'm terribly upset. I wouldn't for worlds have him think I encouraged her in going there.
Mom Beck?
What, honey?
What's a poorhouse?
Oh, that's the place where they send people who got no money.
Is it nice?
No, honey. It's a terrible place. The people there wear rags, and all they get to eat is corn dodgers out of tin pans.
Then I don't want my mother to have to go there.
Oh, why, honey child, your mother won't never have to go to no poorhouse. We wouldn't let that happen, would we, Brother Walker?
I should say not.
Now don't you worry your pretty little head about things like that. The Lord always provides.
Amen!
Mom Beck, why do they dunk the women in the river that way?
That's to save their souls and wash their sins away.
Will it wash my sins away?
Well, honey, you ain't got no sins. You is a little angel.
Well, would it wash my sins away if I had any?
Yes, honey. If you carried the right thought and believed it would.
Were you ever dunked, Mom Beck?
A little river like that wouldn't do her no good. Child, she needs the Mississippi!
That was your grandmother, dear. And that was her song you just sang.
I know. My mother teached it to me. Teached isn't right, is it?
No, taught is correct.
Taught, then. What was my grandmother's name?
Her name was Amanthis.
Amanthis? That's a beautiful name.
She was a beautiful person. With a beautiful soul.
I wish she was here now.
You do, dear? Why?
I know if she was here, she'd go right to my mother and kiss away all of her sorry feelings.
Let's get back to this game. These men are yours. Now, I'll be the Confederacy, and you'll be the Union.
Oh, goody, goody, goody! I got the winning side already.
Oh, no, you haven't! I'll show you!
Maybe you'd like to be the North, and I'll be the South?

Child, you're a true Lloyd. You've got all the fire and courage our family's always had. And you've got the same infernal temper that's been our curse. It's going to cause you a lot of unhappiness unless you learn to control it. Will you try?
I will if you will.
Well, you've got a lot more time to learn than I have.
Tell me, dear, what happened?
Swazey and Hull were thieves. The land they sold me was worthless. We're ruined. We haven't a penny.
Jack, is all our money gone?
All of it. When I found out I got swindled, I almost went crazy. And on top of it, I got this fever.
Hush, dear. Don't think of that now. You must be quiet.
Poor Elizabeth. You made a sorry bargain when you gave up your beautiful home to marry me.
I'd do it again.
What are you wearing those old clothes for? Why don't they dress you up when you go visiting? It isn't showing proper respect to send you off in the oldest things you have.
They're the best I've got, and I like them. And anyway, I don't need any new ones because pretty soon we'll be going away.
Going away? Where?
To the poorhouse!
Do you have the deed here?
It's at my bank.
Well, you bring it here, and I'll have a check for you. That's the way the Union-Pacific does business!
This is more cure than all the medicine. I'm well again!
Oh no, you're not! You just stay right here.

The best part of it is, we won't have to ask your father for anything, and he can't laugh at me for being a failure! Darling, you go to the bank. I'll give you a note to take to Mr. Jennings. You bring back all the papers I left there. The deed is with them.
Oh, it's almost too good to be true!
You oughta be glad to see us. We're old friends of yours.
We've come a long way to see your daddy. Where is he?
He's at home, and he's sick.
Gee, that's too bad.
Where's home?
Down at the end of the road.
Thanks, Colonel. You're still a colonel, I suppose? Well, goodbye.
Oh, those are bad men! I heard Papa Jack say so.
Why, Jack, old partner! What's happened to you?
I've been very ill.

Gee, that's too bad. Anything we can do? Maybe when you find out what we've come for, you'll feel better. When we sold you that land, we did it in good faith. We thought there was gold and plenty on it, and then we went off to California. On our way back, we stopped to see how you were faring, and we found out what had happened. Partner, we felt bad. Didn't we?
That's right.
Now we'll prove we're honest. We made a long trip to find you to give you back your money.
You did, did you?
Why, I couldn't sleep again if I thought you'd lost money. All we ask is that you hand over the deed to the property, and we'll pay you what you paid us, fair and square.
That's very kind and generous of you. Now be kind enough to get out of my house! You found out my land was valuable and the railroad wanted it, and I found out what kind of men you are. Now get out!
Now partner, we came here to make an honest business deal for that deed. But if you're going to get rough about it, we'll have to get it another way.
Grandfather, Grandfather!
What under the sun? Why, child, what is it? What's the matter?
Oh, Grandfather, you've gotta come with me right away!
Come where?
Home to my house. There are two bad men there, and they're saying bad things to Papa Jack!
I wouldn't set foot in that house for anybody or anything!
But you've got to! Papa Jack is sick, and those two men are going to hurt him!
Why should I help a Yankee?
Because he's my papa, and I love him!
Walker, I want you to go to town on Saturday and buy a lot of little girls clothes.
What shall I buy, sir?
Well, what do you suppose? Hats, shoes, stockings, dresses, and whatever goes under the dresses. And Walker?
Yes, sir?
I'm an old fool.
Yes, sir!
[first lines]

[singing]
Oh the days are gone when beauty bright my heart's chain wove, / When my dream of life from morn 'till night was love still love. / New hope may bloom and days may come of milder, calmer beam, / But there's nothing half so sweet in life as love's young dream. / Oh there's nothing half so sweet in life as love's young dream.

[to Lloyd]
Completely armed except for your golden curls, brown eyes and your dimples, you've captured an entire regiment.
[last lines]
What's going on around here?
